context: With advances in medicinal chemistry, most modern antibacterials are <a4_0><b11_0>semisynthetic modifications<b11_0/><a4_0/> of <a0_0>various natural compounds<a0_0/>. These include, for example, the <a5_0><b12_0>beta-lactam antibiotics<b12_0/><a5_0/>, which include the <a2_0><b9_0>penicillins<b9_0/><a2_0/> (produced by <a3_0><b10_0>fungi<b10_0/><a3_0/> in the genus Penicillium), the cephalosporins, and the carbapenems. Compounds that are still isolated from living organisms are the <a6_0>aminoglycosides<a6_0/>, whereas other antibacterials—for example, the sulfonamides, the quinolones, and the oxazolidinones—are produced solely by chemical <a7_0>synthesis<a7_0/>. Many antibacterial compounds are relatively small molecules with a molecular weight of less than <a1_0><b8_0>2000 atomic mass units<b8_0/><a1_0/>.[citation needed]
